{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3501333,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T02:39:55.727Z","cooked":"

So I am our only programmer for this season, well actually I should specify I will likely be the only one doing the programming, I know HOW to code, that’s not the issue, the only issue is coming up with ideas and actually where to start. I’ve been looking at Mechanical Advantage’s code and I like the way they structure their code with their IO subsystems and such, and I like the concept of being able to replay our matches after the fact. I think my problem is I don’t know actually WHAT needs to be coded, we are using an elevator, we have swerve which I just used ctre swerve generator for and then did a little tuning, and we will have a fairly simple algae intake and coral intake. So people of chief delphi, where the heck do I start?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T02:39:55.727Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":98.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/accumulation-of-beginner-programming-resources/507044","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Accumulation of Beginner Programming Resources","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/1","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3501382,"name":"","username":"w1zxrd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/w1zxrd/{size}/246745_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T03:41:33.697Z","cooked":"

Hi!
Last year (our rookie season), we were in a similar boat (and still are). If you’re interested in talking more in-depth with our programmers (me, and one other person) please reach out to us at robotics@neiacademy.org.

My suggestions:
Focus on abstracting as much as you can- the less very specific low-level control you have to do, the more it will simplify tasks for you- especially when you’re working during competitions, in the pits.
We implemented 6328’s IO abstraction strategy last year, and it worked pretty well for us- no real issues. We’re continuing to use it this year. I suggest coding the subsystem classes themselves to find what methods you’ll need, then creating interface classes for each subsystem with methods that suit your subsystem class - elevator, algae intake, coral intake - and then coding the specific implementations with the motor type.

Question- are you doing any vision implementation, or auto routines at all? It’s time-consuming- and perhaps not a priority, but this is also something you may want to consider about how you’re going to approach it.

For which subsystems to focus on- probably start with the most basic, and then work your way up- but this will probably depend on your specific situation.

My suggestion for implementing AdvantageScope - leave it until next year, or between your competitions- don’t focus on it as a priority. In our experience, it’s quite complex to implement this close to the season (we tried about 2-3 weeks out from our first comp) and can end up wasting time. If you can implement it while coding everything else, that’s great - but don’t waste time on it.

You could look at our 2024 code base for an idea on how to get started implementing something like 6328’s IO subsystems on a simpler level - but it is a little messy - GitHub - NEIA-Robotics-9644/2024-Robot-Code: Code for our robot for the 2024 Crescendo FRC Season

You could also take a look at our 2025 code base - we’ve started implementing advantagekit and have added some key changes, though not a ton of work has been done with subsystems just yet - GitHub - NEIA-Robotics-9644/2025-Robot-Code

Again, if you need anything, shoot us an email! We can meet over zoom, or just converse here.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T03:41:33.697Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":48.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/NEIA-Robotics-9644/2024-Robot-Code","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - NEIA-Robotics-9644/2024-Robot-Code: Code for our robot for the 2024 Crescendo FRC Season","clicks":3},{"url":"https://github.com/NEIA-Robotics-9644/2025-Robot-Code","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - NEIA-Robotics-9644/2025-Robot-Code","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63685,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9644 Captain + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/2","custom_user_title":"9644 Captain + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501395,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T03:57:42.798Z","cooked":"

Hey there! I’m the colead of the 3414 Hackbots programming team. Here’s my best effort to summarize what I think may help:

0 - identify/design subsystems

Just like the other members of the team, you have to design some subsystems - only in code rather than nuts and bolts.

It looks like you already have a good understanding of what you’ll be working with. This is really good.
For each subsystem, you can begin by figuring out what the subsystem needs to control. This includes connected motors, sensors, etc. Make sure that you have read the docs on whatever you may need included. You want an IR sensor? Read the docs? You’re including a motor? Find the docs, then read them.

As you identify different subsystems, you will amass a lot of information. Write it down somewhere (I personally like markdown, but you do you).

After this, you can start to think about what features your robot code needs. You have an intake. We’ll start there. What features may you need of this “intake”? Does it need a method setIntakeSpeed()? What about hasGamepiece()? At this point, we don’t need syntactically correct code, but rather we need some form of psuedocode that just lets you get your ideas out. Don’t be slowed down by the limitations of Java syntax.

The amount of operations that a subsystem should be responsible for will increase as you design further. But that’s a problem for when you implement more features - later.

1 - shell subsystems

Once you have decided which features and responsibilities your subsystem needs - like needs - we can begin writing some code. It really at this point doesn’t matter how you choose to implement it, in terms of file structure or naming. We just need a basic implementation for what we are looking for. You don’t need to implement the most advanced stuff yet. If you’re looking to get started, we need something in code that technically does what we need. It doesn’t need to do it well - but don’t let that mean that you shouldn’t implement good practices and clever ideas. By all means, make your code nice if you can. But that’s not your very first priority. Getting your code to build and function as expected is a good starting point, especially if it’s just you writing all the code.

2 - designing commands

After your subsystems are in place with the obvious operations, we can start to build some commands. Again, just like with the subsystems, you can throw all of your ideas into some psuedocode or markdown. This lets you dump your ideas out and see what works.

When designing commands, let’s try to consider the following questions:

  • When does this run?
  • What assumptions are we making about our robot/code?
    This is particularly important. Jot down your assumptions so that you know what you need to make sure works later.
  • What state should the robot be in at the command init?
  • What initialization does this command need?
  • What does the command do?
  • What needs to be read/written to subsystems?
  • When will our command be triggered?
    This one is a little harder, because we haven’t planned this out yet. Come back to it if you must.
  • When will our command end?

3 - writing commands

Then, we can start writing the commands.
From a personal design aspect, while I write my commands, I pretend that my subsystem can do anything. Any methods that it needs, I have. Implementing those is our next step. For now, we pretend like the subsystems can do whatever they should (reasonably) be able to do. Consult step 0 to figure out what the subsystems are physically capable of.

Note: Don’t forget to call addRequirements() for your subsystems. That is so crucial, but so easy to miss. It’ll save you a headache down the road.

Sadly, your code will very much not build yet. But that’s fine.

3 - beefing up subsystems

Now, our commands lay out a very easy to follow structure of what exactly the subsystems need to do. Using the commands as specifications for what your subsystems can do, get to work! Implement whatever features you already deemed necessary for those subsystems, and soon, your subsystems will expand and have so much functionality.

4 - connecting commands to the robot

You’ve written all of your subsystem code and commands! That’s awesome. Now we need a way to trigger those commands. This part is more of a team-specific design choice, so I can’t offer too much advice.
But you can ask yourself these questions to get an idea:

  • During what part of the game (auton, teleop, endgame) should this command run?
  • Does this command run in parallel/sequence with other commands? Which ones?

If you have decided that a command should be triggered on a button, consider if it should be strictly while the button is pressed down, or if the command starts on button press and terminates by itself?

Also, talk to the driver(s) about where to put the buttons. You’re designing it for them, so let them choose what is best.

5 - test

Now, let’s see what works.

PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE consider using simulation before running any robot code!

Simulation is awesome, and it can even let you see the simulated motor position/velocities for motors in the system. You can simulate and trigger IR sensors, and see their effects on the robot.

After simulation lets you fix the logical errors in your code, it’s time to connect to an actual bot. After getting CAN IDs configured (make sure they line up in code! Lots of problems can be averted this way), you can test your code on a real robot. This could be a comp bot, or it could be a roborio connected to some motors with the same IDs. Up to you.

One of the biggest pieces of advice our mentors have told is is this:

break your code.

Your programming skills will probably have made sure that in the regular cases, the code works as it should. But find those places where it doesn’t, and break your code. Make the robot misbehave by trying strange things. Make sure your code is robust and can operate in a variety of situations.

One thing I’ve learned with robot code is to never assume anything works successfully. In the words of a mentor, “It’s broke until you prove it isn’t.”

6 - improve

By this point, you can relax. Your code works, and you’ve gotten a viable product to your team. But in terms of the code, is it your best work?

This is the point where you can look over/review whatever code you’ve written so far. Look for repeated code, or other strange logic. This is where you can be creative and come up with innovative solutions, so go for it!

Nicer code not only reads better, but also is less of a pain to maintain.

7 - repeat

Ask your team what else the robot needs to be able to do. Look for ways to improve, and implement solutions. If you have a good idea, double check that it would actually help the team and isn’t just a cool novel thing. You serve the team - help them do as good as they can. Give them what they need, not what you think. On the other hand though, bring up new ideas! You can’t know if an idea will be helpful unless you bring it up.

And that’s it! You’ve programmed your bot.

Here’s a list of misc. tips that I would recommend:

  • use version control well
  • make sure to test code when you can
  • read the docs
  • Get continuous feedback
  • read the docs, some more.
  • check out other’s code for help/inspiration.

I would like to think that my team’s code is a good example of most of this, so here’s a link to our repo on github:

3414 Hackbots

Best of luck, and don’t hesitate to ask questions! (I’ll try my best to respond in a timely manner).

I do plan on trying to create some auto paths and implementing vision (we have a limelight), although I’m aware this is a giant workload for just one dude, so these are last-ish priority. (although I know everyone on my team is gonna want some cool autos) I will definitely email yall if you wanna guide me a little bit!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:01:15.956Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":18.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63685,"username":"w1zxrd","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/w1zxrd/{size}/246745_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/4","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501410,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:11:02.512Z","cooked":"

Wow! Thanks for writing so much, and this was exactly the kind of response I was hoping for, and I’m glad to see I was on the right track for a lot of it, my problem has been trying to write good and the most efficient code for everything, where as you pointed out, it just has to work until I have the NEED to improve it and should improve it.

I have a couple questions:

  1. How exactly do you do simulation? Like I’ve seen it be done by our mentor team (2556), but what exactly should you simulate? I know you don’t need a full CAD model of your robot (we actually don’t even have a person who is capable of that so…) or even a visual representation of your robot, you can just simulate what it would do with the built in simulator to WPILIB?
  2. How do you know the code needs improvement? For example, lets say your code works well, but you think it could perform better if it was made a different way, would you improve it in that situation? (I’m assuming so)
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:11:02.512Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65568,"username":"therekrab","name":"Nolan Barker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/5","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501425,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:23:57.153Z","cooked":"

I’m glad to hear I could help!

  1. Simulation

Simulation is for some reason deceivingly simple to implement:

A lot of the external classes (TalonFX from CTRE, for example) already include simulation baked in. In WPILib VS Code, the WPILib > Simulate Robot Code command will open a GUI called Glass. Glass is helpful, because it lets you see the position of all motors/devices that you’ve instantiated. For example, a regularly created motor will show up in the simulation window.

For more info on Glass, read here.

Plus, I’d bet that there’s a lot of Chief Delphi posts that are in more detail.

So in response to what we simulate, it’s pretty much just the motors that we do. One guy on the team figured out how to use the MechanismLigament2d type to put like sliding lines on glass to represent the position of an elevator, which is cool but not necessary.

  1. Improvement - This is really not a very sciency approach, but I improve code if I’m looking at it afterwards and have the feeling that it’s messy. If your code doesn’t look easy to follow, you are either building something inherently complex, or your code can be simplified. Honestly, it’s personal preference. If you can tolerate your code, then there’s no reason to change anything. But if you are writing it, and you think, “But wait! I could be really clever and do it this way…” then that’s a sign that there may be a better way to implement something.

A good test would be seeing how easy it is to explain the code to a friend/mentor/yourself. It’s really quite abstract, and it’s more of intuition that you develop that lets you know you can improve it.

One example I’ll give is this:

Many writes on CAN traffic are not ideal. If I have some command, and it calls a subsystem method goFast() every execute run, that results in a lot of CAN traffic (talking to the motors). To mitigate unnecessary traffic, you could use some logic inside of the subsystem to keep track of the most recent applied input to the motor. Then, you only apply a new input if it doesn’t match the old.

Really, refactoring and improvement really should only be considered if you are having problems with you code, because a one man programming squad already has enough to deal with.

But if you keep using a subsystem’s method(s) and saying, “Man, this stinks. I wish I had…”, you can take the time to make some changes that make it easier to improve in the future.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:23:57.153Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/wpilib-tools/robot-simulation/index.html#robot-simulation","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Robot Simulation — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65624,"username":"10219Ryba","name":"Carter Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/6","custom_user_title":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501439,"name":"M","username":"Mako","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mako/{size}/270886_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:41:15.114Z","cooked":"

Sorta related what if your the only person who wants to program at the moment and no one knows how to program or teach you (java)?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:41:15.114Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485034,"topic_slug":"where-to-get-started-when-coding","display_username":"M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68890,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Hachan Supporter"},"post_url":"/t/where-to-get-started-when-coding/485034/7","custom_user_title":"Hachan Supporter","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501442,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:51:25.283Z","cooked":"

Obviously I’m not the most experienced here, but from my experience just trying to code something really helps, the WPILIB docs were pretty useful in that aspect of just teaching some really simple stuff, now if you’re going to stuff more complicated like swerve drive theres a lot of other great tools like YAGSL and obviously the CTRE swerve drive generator (only if you have all CTRE products), and honestly just watching basic tutorials and doing the codecademy courses really taught me a lot too. Remember if no one else is willing to do it and you manage to make SOMETHING that’s a success, and even if you weren’t able to make anything work but no one else even tried, then is that really your fault?

I’m in the same boat as you so what I did was got what my team wanted in our code and went to google found this

github.com

allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples at main ·...

Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC. Contribute to wpilibsuite/allwpilib development by creating an account on GitHub.

I put the code in and adjusted everything that we didn’t need or it didn’t have.

if that link doesn’t have what you’re looking for come back and ask what you guys need and see if a team has old code you can use and adjust as your team sees fit

(if this isn’t what you’re looking for sorry)
